Name: Agriculture present
Description: Agriculture (horticulture) present (i.e., food plants cultivated)

Name: Agriculture is primary subsistence
Description: Agriculture provides the major part of subsistence (about 75% or more)

Name: Agricultural plots permanently cultivated
Description: Agricultural plots under relatively permanent cultivation except for periods of fallow (if they occur)

Name: Improved techniques of planting
Description: Improved techniques of planting (e.g., mounds, planting in rows, breaking of clods, plowing)

Name: Soil-working or harvesting tools
Description: Soil-working tools other than the digging stick (e.g., hoe, spade, rake, footplow) or harvesting tools other than simple beating stick (e.g., flail, rice header, winnowing tray)

Name: Animal-drawn plow
Description: Animal-drawn plow

Name: Fertilization of land
Description: Fertilization of land with material other than wood ashes (including, e.g., animal manure, night soil, green manure, compost, fresh soil or mud)

Name: Crop rotation
Description: Crop rotation

Name: Increasing cultivable land by engineering methods
Description: Area of cultivable land increased by engineering methods, including drainage, irrigation, and terracing

Name: Reclamation of agricultural land by drainage
Description: Reclamation of agricultural land by drainage

Name: Irrigation
Description: Irrigation

Name: Permanent dams or dykes
Description: Permanent dams or dykes to impound water for irrigation, drinking, etc.

Name: Terracing
Description: Terracing (including barriers to reduce soil slippage)

Name: Continuous boundaries delimit agricultural fields
Description: Continuous boundaries (other than growing food plants) delimit agricultural fields (e.g., fences, rows or walls of stone, paths, ditches, hedges)

Name: Agricultural land reverted
Description: Agricultural land reverts to chief, king or state as personal property or for reassignment when owner abandons the land or dies without heirs (i.e., escheat)

Name: Agricultural land reapportioned
Description: Agricultural lands reapportioned from time to time by the chief, tribe, or state to insure equitable distribution and/or maximum cultivation, rather than for services rendered

Name: State enforcement of maximum cultivation
Description: Agricultural land forfeited by a cultivator for failure to till it properly (i.e., state enforcement of maximum cultivation)

Name: Agricultural cycle determined by specialists
Description: Political or religious officials or other specialists determine the time of carrying out various steps in the agricultural cycle

Name: State or church provides farmers with equipment
Description: State or church provides farmers with seed or tools

Name: Regular food surplus production
Description: Surplus of food regularly produced over and above the annual subsistence needs of the food producers, and not consumed by them

Name: State or tribal granaries
Description: State or tribal granaries on which two or more communities (or the army) might draw

Name: Fruit or nut orchards planted
Description: Fruit or nut orchards planted

Name: Domesticated animals other than dogs
Description: Domesticated animals kept (other than the dog)

Name: Domesticated animals kept to provide food
Description: Domesticated animals kept to provide food

Name: Domesticated animals used for packing
Description: Domesticated animals used for packing

Name: Domesticated animals used for traction
Description: Domesticated animals used for traction

Name: Domesticated animals used for riding
Description: Domesticated animals used for riding

Name: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years
Description: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years, on the average

Name: Settlements permanent
Description: Settlements permanent

Name: Rectangular ground plan for settlements
Description: Rectangular ground plan for settlements

Name: Communities of 100 or more
Description: Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 100 or more members

Name: Communities of 500 or more
Description: Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 500 or more members

Name: Towns of 2,000 or more
Description: Towns: permanent nucleated settlements of 2,000 or more residents

Name: Two or more towns
Description: Two or more towns

Name: City of 10,000 or more
Description: City: administrative and commercial population center of at least 10,000 residents, most of whom are engaged in non-subsistence activities

Name: Two or more cities
Description: Two or more cities

Name: City of 100,000 or more
Description: City of 100,000 or more residents

Name: Cities divided into quarters or wards
Description: Cities divided into quarters or wards

Name: Planned cities
Description: Planned cities

Name: Paved streets
Description: Paved streets

Name: Paved plaza
Description: Paved plaza

Name: Well-maintained roads connecting settlements
Description: Broad and well-maintained roads connecting settlements

Name: Paved roads connecting settlements
Description: Paved roads connecting settlements

Name: Bridges
Description: Bridges (excluding log spans, vine ropes, and simple pole frameworks)

Name: Way stations or inns
Description: Permanently staffed way stations or inns along roads to house and provide for travelers

Name: Civic or ceremonial structures
Description: Civic or ceremonial structures (including men's house) not ordinarily used as dwellings by family units (excluding structures built for specific occasions and later abandoned or destroyed)

Name: Grandstands, amphitheaters, or stadiums
Description: Grandstands, amphitheaters, or stadiums where spectators can witness contests or performances

Name: Stone monuments commemorating persons or events
Description: Stone monuments or stelae to mark or commemorate important persons or events

Name: Aqueducts or conduits
Description: Aqueducts or conduits of stone or brick to supply drinking water

Name: Cisterns
Description: Cisterns: artificially lined rain-catching or water-holding basins

Name: Baths of stone or brick
Description: Baths of stone or brick

Name: Drains
Description: Drains: lined channels, covered or uncovered, or pipes, used to carry off rain water

Name: Sewers
Description: Sewers: lined and covered channels or pipes, primarily for carrying away human waste

Name: Permanent fortifications
Description: Permanent fortifications (including palisades around settlements, blockhouses, citadels, and fortified boundaries, but excluding fortified dwellings or compounds)

Name: Stone or brick fortification walls
Description: Walls of stone, brick, adobe, or beaten earth (including earthworks) used in fortification

Name: Moats
Description: Moats (excluding dry ditches) surrounding fortifications

Name: Parts of houses extensively painted or carved
Description: House walls, ceiling, or roof extensively painted or carved

Name: Multi-room dwellings
Description: Multi-roomed dwellings (three or more walled-off and separate rooms, with some degree of functional differentiation between them)

Name: Multi-storied structures
Description: Multi-storied structures (not meant to include high storage platforms)

Name: Cut stone masonry
Description: Cut stone masonry

Name: Stone or brick bases for civic or ceremonial structures
Description: Stone or brick substructures (e.g., platforms, truncated pyramids) used as bases for civic or ceremonial structures

Name: Dwellings of cut stones
Description: Dwellings (including walls) constructed of cut stones

Name: Civic or ceremonial buildings of cut stone
Description: Civic or ceremonial buildings constructed of cut stone

Name: Monumental architecture of stone or brick
Description: Monumental architecture of stone or brick (e.g., pyramids, palaces, temples, fortresses, amphitheaters)

Name: Quarrying of stone for construction
Description: Quarrying of stone for construction (rather than merely dressing loose stones)

Name: Stone coursing
Description: Stone coursing (blocks laid in successive horizontal layers)

Name: Rubble used between walls in stone or brick construction
Description: Rubble or some other fill used between walls in stone or brick construction

Name: Fired brick used in construction
Description: Fired brick used in construction

Name: True mortar used in construction
Description: True mortar used in construction

Name: Facing of stone or brick walls
Description: Facing of stone or brick walls with plaster, alabaster, etc.

Name: Roof of tile, brick, stone slabs, planks, etc.
Description: Roofs of tile, brick, stone slabs, planks, etc. (i.e., not bark, mud, thatching, or similar material)

Name: Stone lintels
Description: Stone lintels

Name: Corbeled arch
Description: Corbeled arch

Name: True arch
Description: True arch

Name: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally
Description: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally

Name: Stone stairways
Description: Stone stairways (of cut blocks, or carved into living rock)

Name: Architectural stone carving
Description: Architectural stone carving (beyond the cutting of stone into blocks)

Name: Architectural features cut into living rock
Description: Architectural features (e.g., tombs, stairways) cut into living rock

Name: Fortresses built of stone or brick
Description: Fortresses built of stone or brick (including walled cities and citadels, where people take refuge in time of war)

Name: Elaborations in fortified walls
Description: Elaborations in fortified walls (e.g., towers, salients, merlons)

Name: Professional architects or engineers
Description: Professional (full-time) architects or engineers

Name: Professional stone masons
Description: Professional (full-time) stone masons

Name: Professional carpenters or woodworkers
Description: Professional (full-time) carpenters or woodworkers

Name: Landed property
Description: Landed property: continuous ownership rights exercised by individuals or families over land which has been improved, even after cultivated plot, house site, etc., is abandoned

Name: Inscription of land or other forms of property
Description: Inscription of land or other forms of property (registry of deeds)

Name: Most individual property inherited
Description: Most individual (not family) property transmitted by inheritance rather than being destroyed at death of owner

Name: Testamentary disposition of property
Description: Testamentary disposition of property, by a written will, through a formal executor, or orally in the presence of a witness

Name: Wealth differences among society members
Description: Marked differences in wealth (e.g., real property, livestock, precious metals, slaves) among members of the society (other than the difference between the principal political leader and everyone else)

Name: Luxury items
Description: Luxury items (other than symbols of political or religious office) which only a small percentage of the population (less than 20 percent) can afford

Name: Craft specialization
Description: Craft specialization: some crafts which only a limited number of men in the society practice (excluding the making of religious or ceremonial objects by shamans or priests)

Name: Craft production for economic exchange
Description: A significant amount of craft production primarily for economic exchange rather than for personal consumption

Name: Full-time craft specialists
Description: Full-time craft-specialists (e.g., brewer, lapidary, tailor, baker, tanner)

Name: Full-time service specialists
Description: Full-time skilled service specialists (e.g., tattooer, barber, accountant, lawyer, physician)

Name: Guilds of specialized artisans
Description: Guilds of specialized artisans (i.e., cooperative associations)

Name: State controls certain aspects of production
Description: State controls certain aspects of production (e.g., licenses salt production, promotes raising of livestock, monopolizes weapons production, restricts private mining)

Name: Institutional employment of artisans and laborers
Description: Artisans and laborers attached to or employed on a regular basis (rather than under the corvée) by political or religious institutions (tribe or state, temple or church)

Name: Corvée
Description: Corvée (draft labor exacted by a supra-community authority or agency)

Name: Wage labor
Description: Wage labor (unskilled laborers paid in money or in kind at prearranged rates and intervals)

Name: Standardized medium of exchange
Description: Standardized medium of exchange, in terms of which the value of most commodities is reckoned

Name: Coined money
Description: Coined money

Name: Money or goods lent out at interest
Description: Money or goods lent out at interest

Name: Rental of land or dwellings
Description: Rental of land or dwellings by landlords to tenants as a common system of tenure

Name: Itinerant merchants or traders
Description: Itinerant merchants or traders who are members of the society itself (rather than foreigners), and who remain such even if they trade outside the society

Name: Sedentary merchants
Description: Sedentary merchants who operate fixed commercial establishments

Name: Markets
Description: Markets, in which a variety of goods are traded

Name: Daily and permanent markets
Description: Daily and permanent markets

Name: State regulation of commerce
Description: State regulation of commerce (e.g., taxes on economic transactions, fixing of price levels, enforcing payment of debts, supervising markets)

Name: Legally enforceable economic contracts
Description: Economic transactions detailed in legally enforceable contracts

Name: Long-term commercial records kept
Description: Long-term commercial records kept

Name: Recorded inventories of wealth
Description: Recorded inventories of wealth (e.g., with pebbles, knotted cords, notched sticks, clay tablets)

Name: Royal storehouse or treasury
Description: Royal storehouse or treasury (for hard goods, rather than for food) with accountant or treasurer who keeps track of the king's wealth

Name: Trade between communities
Description: Trade between communities

Name: Trade with other societies
Description: Frequent or regular trade with other societies, involving journeys of at least 3 days one-way

Name: State-directed trade
Description: State-directed trade (i.e., trade carried on by agents of the state with other societies)

Name: Trading outposts
Description: Trading outposts maintained outside the territory of the society

Name: Taxation in kind
Description: Taxation in kind (including produce from land farmed for the state, but excluding required contributions to community projects or ceremonies)

Name: Taxation in money
Description: Taxation in money

Name: Official tax or tribute collectors
Description: Official tax or tribute collectors sent out periodically by the central government

Name: Tolls
Description: Tolls collected on roads or bridges

Name: Serfs
Description: Serfs: propertyless class of agricultural laborers, bound to the land and producing for their masters

Name: Extrasocietal slavery
Description: War captives or persons bought outside the society kept as slaves and usually not adopted, liberated, or killed subsequently (i.e. extrasocietal slavery)

Name: Intrasocietal slavery
Description: Debtors or criminals made slaves, or other freeborn members of the society (including wives and children) sold into slavery (i.e., intrasocietal slavery)

Name: Slaves bought and sold within the society
Description: Slaves bought and sold within the society (excluding the selling into slavery of freeborn members of the society)

Name: Social segments above family
Description: Social segments above the level of the extended family or household (e.g., lineages, sibs, moieties, marriage classes, castes, age grades, men's clubs, secret societies, warrior societies, ceremonial teams, craft guilds)

Name: Unilineal kin groups beyond families
Description: Unilineal kin groups beyond extended families (including royal lineages)

Name: Significant social status differences
Description: Well-defined and significant differences in social status (other than the difference between the principal political leader and everyone else)

Name: Social stratification into at least three classes
Description: Stratification of society into at least three distinct social classes (e.g., kings, nobles, commoners, slaves)

Name: Two or more ranked groups of upper classes
Description: Upper classes differentiated into two or more ranked groups

Name: Ornaments or clothing distinguishing social classes
Description: Special ornaments or differences in clothing which distinguish members of the upper classes from the rest of the society

Name: Sumptuary laws
Description: Sumptuary laws concerning dress, adornment, or other manifestations of wealth and serving to maintain class distinctions

Name: Upper class members have superior residences
Description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) have distinctly superior residences

Name: Upper class members have more land
Description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) have significantly more land or property than commoners

Name: Upper class members are extempt from taxation
Description: Members of upper classes (outside of the royal family) are extempt from taxation

Name: Upper class members have servants or retainers
Description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) have permanent servants or retainers

Name: Upper class members have numerous wives or concubines
Description: Members of upper classes usually have numerous wives or concubines (at least 4 or 5)

Name: Competitive sports or spectacles held for the upper classes
Description: Competitive sports or spectacles held primarily for the entertainment of the upper classes

Name: Dramatic performances for upper class entertainment
Description: Dramatic performances held primarily for the entertainment of the upper classes

Name: Professional dancers or musicians for upper classes
Description: Professional dancers or musicians who provide entertainment during feasts, banquets, or celebrations of the upper classes

Name: Class differences in disposal of the dead
Description: Status or class differences in disposal of the dead (based on social rather than religious status; exclude shamans and priests)

Name: Upper class members buried with luxury goods
Description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) buried with luxury goods

Name: Upper class members buried with wives, retainers or slaves
Description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) buried with wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves

Name: Upper class members elaborately buried
Description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) buried in elaborate tombs or graves (e.g., burial mounds, cist graves, thatched buildings)

Name: Supra-community political units
Description: Communities (or camps) continuously grouped (year-round) into larger political units

Name: Supra-provincial political organization
Description: Districts or provinces, each comprising several villages or communities, are permanently grouped into a larger political unit

Name: State
Description: State: permanent organization of a number of supra-community units (districts, tribes, or provinces) into a single political unit under centralized control, involving at least (a) some power to collect revenue, (b) some centralized judicial authority, and (c) the power to formulate and execute policy

Name: Empire
Description: Empire: a unit of two or more formerly independent states covering a considerable area

Name: Headman, chief, king, or council
Description: Decisions or policy made by a formally recognized agent or agency of the society (e.g., headman, chief, king, or council in which membership is not based merely on age or sex)

Name: Political leader has considerable authority
Description: Political leader(s) has considerable authority, by virtue of his office rather than his personality

Name: Regular advisors to political leader
Description: Regular advisor(s) or assistant(s) to the principal political leader (e.g., sub-chief, talking chief, minister, council)

Name: Political leader is a full-time specialist
Description: Political leader is a full-time specialist (i.e., does not regularly engage in subsistence)

Name: Monarchy
Description: Monarchy: a government in which the king is the ultimate source of authority and exercises such powers as the following: the power to conscript an army or a labor force, strong executive power, the power to declare war, the power of life and death, etc.

Name: Capital city or town
Description: State or tribe has capital city or town

Name: Provincial administrative centers
Description: Provincial or district administrative centers where officials appointed by the state (other than local chiefs) collect taxes or maintain order

Name: Governors
Description: Governors or chiefs, appointed or confirmed in office, in charge of administering districts or provinces

Name: Three or more levels of territorial administration
Description: Three or more levels of territorial administration above the community (e.g., 1. district, 2. province, 3. quarter, 4. kingdom)

Name: Municipal officials
Description: Officials in charge of municipal administration (e.g., mayors, bailiffs)

Name: Hierarchy of non-territorial administrative officials
Description: Hierarchy of non-territorial administrative officials (exclude palace hierarchy)

Name: State ministers
Description: State ministers in charge of various activities controlled or supervised by the state (e.g., minister of agriculture, minister of public works, minister of war, minister of foreign affairs)

Name: Council of ministers advising the ruler
Description: Council of ministers forming a regular advisory body to the ruler

Name: Prime minister
Description: Prime minister: principal administrative officer below the ruler and appointed by him

Name: Three or more levels of administrative officials
Description: Hierarchy of at least three levels of administrative officials (including the paramount chief or king)

Name: Inspectors, censors, or secret agents
Description: Inspectors, censors, or secret agents who investigate the functioning of officials, popular discontent, etc.

Name: Professional civil service
Description: Professional civil service: administrative positions filled on the basis of merit and training, rather than on the basis of kinship ties, wealth, social status, or personal allegiance to the ruler

Name: State-sponsored colonists
Description: State-sponsored colonists

Name: Procedure for political succession
Description: Succession to political leadership by a clear and regularly followed procedure (e.g., primogeniture, formal election)

Name: Political leader appoints officials
Description: Political leader appoints and deposes political officials

Name: Political leader bestows land, slaves, rank
Description: Political leader bestows land, slaves, or noble rank for services rendered

Name: Ruler grants audiences
Description: Ruler grants audiences to hear grievances or petitions

Name: Political leader controls religious institutions
Description: Political leader exercises considerable control over religious institutions (e.g., performs investiture of priests, endows temples)

Name: Full-time retainers for political leader
Description: Political leader has full-time personal attendants and retainers

Name: Ruler has many wives or concubines
Description: Chief or king has many wives or concubines (at least 8 or 10)

Name: Ruler has a harem
Description: Chief or king has a harem (a special residence(s) supervised by a responsible official(s), e.g., a eunuch)

Name: Ruler has a bodyguard
Description: Body guard to protect the ruler's person

Name: Court
Description: Court, characterized by a household staff and steward, resident members of the upper classes, state or tribal officials, entertainers, etc.

Name: Special residence for political leader
Description: Political leader lives in a special residence or compound significantly larger and more elaborate than any other residence

Name: Royal estates
Description: Royal estates, residences, or preserves outside the capital which are the property of the king

Name: Installation ceremony for political leader
Description: Special ceremony for installation or investiture of new political leader (e.g., oath of office, coronation)

Name: Ruler has special symbols of office
Description: Chief or king has special symbols of office or authority (e.g., throne, crown, scepter, seal)

Name: Authentication devices for official actions
Description: Devices used to confirm and authenticate state orders, decrees, actions, and transactions (e.g., seals, signatures, rings, or other graphic evidence)

Name: Deference to political leader
Description: Displays of special deference to political leader (e.g., carrying in a litter, averting the eyes, bowing)

Name: Officials or sub-chiefs swear allegiance to the leader
Description: Officials, sub-chiefs, or courtiers swear allegiance to the king or state

Name: Political leader performs essential societal rituals
Description: Political leader performs rituals considered essential for the welfare of the society, and which only he can perform

Name: (Semi)divine ruler
Description: Ruler considered divine or semi-divine

Name: Ruler buried with luxury goods
Description: Paramount chief or king buried with luxury goods

Name: Ruler elaborately buried
Description: Ruler buried in an elaborate tomb or grave (e.g., burial mound, cist grave, thatched building, pyramid)

Name: Ruler buried with wives or slaves
Description: Wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves of chief or king buried with him at the time of his death

Name: Special preservation of the ruler's corpse
Description: Special preservation (e.g., desiccation, embalming) of the ruler's corpse or part thereof

Name: Deceased political leader reverenced
Description: Deceased former political leader especially reverenced (e.g., his spirit invoked or propitiated, monuments erected to his memory)

Name: Superordinate tribe or state
Description: Superordinate tribe or state which receives tribute, labor, soldiers, or other recognition of obligation from subordinate or vassal tribe(s) or state(s)

Name: Formal treaties
Description: Formal treaties (recorded or witnessed and sworn) concluded to establish alliances, to settle disputes, or to end wars

Name: Ambassadors
Description: Ambassador(s): diplomatic representatives acting in regular relations with a foreign government

Name: Young persons sent to capital for training or royal service
Description: Young persons sent to capital from each district for training or royal service

Name: State schools for upper class members
Description: State schools for secular training of members of the upper classes

Name: Crimes punished by a permanent agent
Description: Crimes regularly punished by a permanent agent of the society rather than by the offended parties themselves

Name: Peace-making machinery
Description: Peace-making machinery or institution for settling disputes and avoiding fighting within the community (either a permanent mediator, e.g., chief or council, whose neutrality and wisdom are generally accepted, or an arbitrator, e.g., the state, backed by sanctions of force)

Name: Inter-community disputes settled by peaceful means
Description: Inter-community disputes within the tribe or state customarily settled by peaceful means (e.g., arbitration, official decrees) rather than by fighting

Name: Judicial process
Description: Judicial process, in which an individual or limited group (e.g., council of elders, tribal chief, court of law) considers evidence and renders judgment in a dispute, or of an accused person, on behalf of the society

Name: Court trials
Description: Court trials, held under judges or magistrates who hear testimony and weigh evidence, interpret the law, and render a decision in civil or criminal cases

Name: Judicial system of higher and lower courts
Description: Judicial system of higher and lower courts, cases being referred to one or the other according to their nature, with decisions of lower courts perhaps appealable to higher courts

Name: Political leader exercises judicial power
Description: Political leader exercises judicial power (decides guilt and decrees punishment, or settles cases appealed to him)

Name: Ruler sometimes pardons convicted offenders
Description: Ruler sometimes pardons convicted offenders

Name: Ruler functions as lawgiver
Description: Ruler functions as lawgiver or lawmaker

Name: Code of laws
Description: Code of laws (explicit and recorded) which covers broad areas of social, political, and economic relations

Name: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses
Description: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses (i.e., members of the various social classes have different rights under the law)

Name: Graded series of punishments
Description: Graded series of punishments or fines specified by a central agency of the society (e.g., tribal council, ruler, legislature) and consistently applied to fit a graded series of offenses

Name: Offenses punished by fines
Description: Certain offenses punished by fines (in money or in kind) paid to tribe or state, of which part may go to the offended party

Name: Offenses punished by confiscation of property
Description: Certain offenses punished by confiscation of property, of which part may go to the offended party

Name: Corporal punishment
Description: Corporal punishment (including mutilation) meted out for certain offenses by an authorized agent of the society

Name: Offenses punished by slavery or hard labor
Description: Certain offenses punished by slavery or by terms at hard labor

Name: Death penalty
Description: Death penalty decreed for certain crimes and exacted openly by a constituted agent of the society

Name: Violation of secular law incurs divine and secular punishment
Description: Violation of secular legal norms automatically incurs punishment by gods as well as secular punishment

Name: Police force
Description: Police force: permanent agency of the state charged with apprehension and detention of criminals

Name: Incarceration of convicted offenders
Description: Incarceration of convicted offenders (in stocks, pens, cages, or prisons)

Name: Economic reasons for warfare
Description: Warfare motivated primarily by economic considerations (e.g., territorial acquisition, the capture of booty, the taking of slaves) rather than by feuds, the avenging of murder or witchcraft, or the taking of women

Name: War leaders
Description: Recognized war leader(s) (distinct from the political leader) who regularly lead(s) the men of the society against the enemy (e.g., war chief, general)

Name: Professional military commanders
Description: Professional military commanders (e.g., generals) who regularly lead the army in time of war

Name: Professional middle-level military officials
Description: Professional middle-level military officials (e.g., centurions, lieutenants, captains)

Name: Specially trained warriors
Description: Body of specially trained or highly skilled warriors

Name: Military conscription
Description: Military conscription

Name: Soldiers take oath of allegiance
Description: Soldiers take oath of allegiance

Name: Standing army
Description: Standing army, organized around a core of professional soldiers

Name: Mercenaries
Description: Mercenaries (i.e., paid foreign troops) used in warfare

Name: Espionage
Description: Espionage, by special agents who pass for natives in enemy territory

Name: Defensive body armor
Description: Defensive body armor (excluding shields)

Name: Pitched battles
Description: Pitched battles: encounters frequently fought hand-to-hand rather than hit-and-run

Name: Military formations and tactics
Description: Military formations and tactics used in warfare (including the holding of men in reserve, but excluding ambushes and hit-and-run raids)

Name: Military emblems and banners
Description: Emblems, banners, or special objects which serve to identify military units and act as rallying points are carried into battle

Name: Differentiated military units
Description: Differentiated military units (e.g., spearmen, bowmen, slingers, cavalry)

Name: Chariots used in warfare
Description: Chariots used in warfare

Name: Permanently garrisoned forts
Description: Permanently garrisoned forts (excluding observation posts, walled towns and cities)

Name: Sieges laid to enemy fortifications
Description: Sieges laid to enemy fortifications strong enough to resist immediate assault

Name: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines
Description: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines

Name: Special ornaments for brave or wounded warriors
Description: Special ornaments, insignia, or appellations awarded for prowess or wounds received in battle

Name: Rewards for outstanding warriors
Description: Outstanding warriors rewarded with gifts of property, women, or slaves

Name: Nobility attainable through war exploits
Description: Nobility or distinctly high social status attainable through war exploits

Name: Body trophies
Description: Body trophies (e.g., heads, scalps, hands) taken in war or from sacrificed prisoners

Name: Adult male war captives
Description: Adult male war captives frequently taken

Name: War captives regularly sacrificed to gods
Description: War captives regularly sacrificed to god(s)

Name: Ransoming of war captives
Description: Ransoming of war captives

Name: Territory of vanquished enemy annexed
Description: Territory of vanquished enemy annexed

Name: Vanquished enemies subjugated and controlled
Description: Peoples of vanquished enemy subjugated and held under effective control

Name: Defeated political leaders pledge loyalty to conquerors
Description: Defeated political leader(s) or his heir retained in authority over his territory on pledge of loyalty to conquerors

Name: Periodic revolts of subject peoples
Description: Periodic revolts of subject peoples

Name: Gods of war
Description: God(s) of war (not necessarily connected exclusively with war)

Name: Gods
Description: God(s): supernatural beings (not impersonal forces) who are not particular to locations or to kinship segments (exclude, e.g., ancestral, guardian, and other personal spirits), to whom prayers are directed and who actively intervene in human affairs

Name: Patron gods
Description: Patron gods (not including guardian spirits), who afford protection to individuals engaged in particular occupations or activities (e.g., god of merchants, god of hunters, god of travelers, god of blacksmiths)

Name: Oracles
Description: Oracle(s): a shrine or object where, or by means of which, a priest or priestess transmits answers to questions posed to a god or spirit

Name: Lawgiver god
Description: Lawgiver god, who on more than one occasion has enunciated extensive rules for governing human conduct

Name: Sun god
Description: Sun god worshipped (i.e., propitiated and invoked)

Name: Pantheon of gods
Description: Pantheon of gods worshipped (propitiated and invoked): applies only to differentiated gods who actively control spheres of life or nature, e.g., rain god, war god, fire god, fertility goddess, love goddess

Name: Paramount god in the pantheon
Description: One god in the pantheon of differentiated gods worshipped as paramount

Name: Idols
Description: Idols worshipped as representations of supernatural beings

Name: Offerings
Description: Offerings, libations, or sacrifices to supernatural beings (gods, ancestors, local spirits)

Name: Human sacrifice
Description: Human sacrifice directed to supernatural beings to placate them or gain their favor

Name: Altars
Description: Altars, where offerings (including sacrifices) or prayers to gods are regularly made or rituals performed

Name: Special religious practitioners
Description: Special religious practitioners (e.g., shamans, priests)

Name: Religious specialists supported by individuals or society
Description: Religious specialist(s) supported (fully or almost fully) by individuals, the community, tribe, or state

Name: Priests
Description: Priests: religious practitioners connected with specific gods or with society-wide ancestral cults; i.e., not shamans

Name: Priests formally invested in their office
Description: Priests formally invested in their office by chief, king, or higher priests

Name: Functionally specialized priests
Description: Functionally specialized priests (e.g., interpreters of oracles or dreams, sacrificial priests, funerary priests)

Name: Hierarchy of priests
Description: Hierarchy of priests

Name: Temples
Description: Temples, where gods are worshipped or society-wide ancestral cults are practiced by priests

Name: Temple has large staff
Description: Temple has large staff (more than 10 )

Name: Temple owns considerable property
Description: Temple owns considerable property

Name: Women consecrated to a temple or a god service
Description: Women consecrated to a temple or to the service of a god (e.g., priestesses, virgins, nuns)

Name: Church
Description: Church: religious institution which encompasses a number of priests and temples (or monks and monasteries) and which is unified by a set of common beliefs and observances

Name: Head priest has considerable political influence
Description: Head priest (including priest-chief or priest-king) has considerable political influence

Name: Church owns large amounts of land
Description: Church owns large amounts of land

Name: Temple or church receives donations
Description: Temple or church receives donations

Name: Temple or church exacts tithes
Description: Temple or church exacts tithes or receives the produce of a proportion of all cultivated lands

Name: Training school for priests
Description: Training school for priests

Name: Priests follow strict rules of discipline
Description: Priests follow strict rules of discipline, including various forms of abegnation (e.g., fasting, continence) or mortification of the flesh

Name: Monasteries, convents, or nunneries
Description: Monasteries, convents, or nunneries where priests, priestesses, etc., live, and which, unlike temples, are ordinarily closed to laymen

Name: Ceremonial or religious center
Description: Ceremonial or religious center: a complex of temples and associated buildings having an important role in the religious life of the society

Name: Religious pilgrimages
Description: Religious pilgrimages to shrines or sacred places

Name: Ritual or liturgical texts
Description: Ritual or liturgical (written) texts

Name: Pottery (either made or commonly used)
Description: Pottery (either made or used commonly)

Name: Painted pottery made
Description: Painted pottery made

Name: Effigy vessels made
Description: Effigy vessels made

Name: Mold-made pottery
Description: Mold-made pottery

Name: Wheel-made pottery
Description: Wheel-made pottery

Name: Pottery kilns
Description: Pottery kilns

Name: Men make the pottery
Description: Men make the pottery

Name: Professional potters
Description: Professional (full-time) potters

Name: Professional painters or sculptors
Description: Professional (full-time) painters or sculptors

Name: Terracotta figurines
Description: Terracotta (baked clay) figurines or statues as art or ceremonial objects

Name: Stone statues
Description: Stone statues (or figurines) as art or ceremonial objects

Name: Heroic or gigantic stone statues
Description: Heroic or gigantic stone statues

Name: Stone reliefs, intaglios, or friezes
Description: Reliefs, intaglios, or friezes carved into dressed stone surfaces

Name: Wall murals or frescoes
Description: Murals or frescoes painted on faced stone or brick walls

Name: Glass manufactured
Description: Glass manufactured

Name: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass
Description: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass

Name: Ground or polished stone cutting tools
Description: Ground or polished stone cutting tools

Name: Metal axes or adzes made
Description: Metal axes or adzes made

Name: Animal-powered devices for grinding grain
Description: Animal-powered devices for grinding grain

Name: Mechanical devices for raising water
Description: Mechanical devices for raising water (e.g., shadoof, water wheel)

Name: Wheeled vehicles
Description: Wheeled vehicles

Name: Scales or balances
Description: Scales or balances

Name: Spindle
Description: Spindle

Name: Heddle loom
Description: Heddle loom

Name: Animal fibers woven into cloth
Description: Hair, wool, fur, or silk woven into cloth

Name: Patterns woven into cloth
Description: Patterns woven into cloth

Name: Garments made of woven cloth
Description: Garments made of woven cloth

Name: Dyeing
Description: Dyeing of finished, loom-woven textiles

Name: Professional weavers
Description: Professional weavers, who weave cloth primarily for exchange

Name: Forging
Description: Forging (hammering metal into shape while hot)

Name: Mining of ores
Description: Mining of ores

Name: Smelting of ores
Description: Smelting of ores

Name: Bellows used in working metal
Description: Bellows used in working metal

Name: Copper mined and worked
Description: Copper mined and worked

Name: Gold and/or silver mined and worked
Description: Gold and/or silver mined and worked

Name: Iron mined and worked
Description: Iron mined and worked

Name: Alloying of metals
Description: Alloying of metals

Name: Bronze or brass produced
Description: Bronze or brass produced

Name: Casting in molds
Description: Casting in molds

Name: Lost-wax casting
Description: Lost-wax casting (cire perdue)

Name: Metal hardening through annealing or tempering
Description: Altering the hardness of metals by annealing (heating and slow cooling) or tempering (heating and rapid cooling by immersion in a liquid)

Name: Soldering, welding, or riveting used to join metals
Description: Soldering, welding, or riveting used to join metals

Name: Decorative metal-working techniques
Description: Decorative metal-working techniques (e.g., gilding, embossing, engraving, inlaying)

Name: Copper tools in common use
Description: Copper weapons or utensils in common use

Name: Bronze tools in common use
Description: Bronze or brass weapons or utensils in common use

Name: Iron tools in common use
Description: Iron weapons or utensils in common use

Name: Metal tools predominant
Description: Metal weapons and utensils predominant

Name: Ornaments and jewelry of precious metals
Description: Ornaments and jewelry of gold, silver, or other precious metals

Name: Non-utllitarian metal objects
Description: Non-utilitarian objects made of metal (e.g., figurines or statues, ceremonial chalices, solar discs)

Name: Precious or semiprecious stones used for jewelry
Description: Precious or semi-precious stones used for jewelry

Name: Professional smiths
Description: Professional smiths, who work metal primarily for exchange

Name: Watercraft
Description: Watercraft (excluding floating logs and simple rafts)

Name: Boats built from several planks
Description: Boats built from several planks (excluding strakes)

Name: Vessels propelled by oars
Description: Vessels propelled by oars

Name: Vessels propelled by sails
Description: Vessels propelled by sails

Name: Cabins on board vessels
Description: Cabins on board vessels

Name: Navy
Description: Navy: fleet of specially designed warships maintained by the state

Name: Professional boatbuilders
Description: Professional boatbuilders (including part-time specialists)

Name: Professional sailors, pilots, or navigators
Description: Professional sailors, pilots, or navigators (including part-time specialists)

Name: Voyages undertaken out of sight of land
Description: Voyages undertaken out of sight of land

Name: Water boiled in a container
Description: Water boiled in a container over a fire, rather than by hot stones dropped into it

Name: Standardized weights and measures
Description: Standardized weights and measures (excluding measurement with parts of the body, and similarly variable measurements)

Name: System of numbers extending beyond 100
Description: System of numbers extending beyond 100

Name: Mathematics
Description: Mathematics (beyond simple addition and subtraction)

Name: Mnemonic devices for recording traditions, events, etc.
Description: Traditions, events, etc., recorded by means of mnemonic devices (excluding simple records of elapsed time or simple inventories)

Name: System of writing
Description: System of writing (including extensive systems of standardized pictographs)

Name: Fully phonetic system of writing
Description: Fully phonetic system of writing

Name: Scribes
Description: Scribes (other than priests)

Name: Teachers
Description: Teachers: professional, secular instructors

Name: Techniques of surveying and mensuration
Description: Techniques of surveying and mensuration (including, e.g., plumb lines, knowledge of right angle, stretched cords, but excluding swinging of circles by means of a cord)

Name: Regular astronomical observations by specialists
Description: Astronomical observations regularly made by priests or other specialists

Name: Calendrical system
Description: Calendrical system, uniquely designating each day of the year, based on solar or stellar observations

Name: Census taken
Description: Census taken

Name: Surgery practiced
Description: Surgery practiced (excluding, e.g., the setting of broken bones, removal of arrows, bloodletting)

Name: Papermaking
Description: Papermaking

Name: Fermented beverages from cultivated plants
Description: Fermented beverages brewed from cultivated plants

Name: Organized messenger or courier system
Description: Organized messenger or courier system which links together most of the society’s territory

Name: Professional bards, musicians, or storytellers
Description: Bards, minstrels, musicians, or storytellers, whose primary activity is to compose, play, or recite songs, poems, or stories
